People Kevin = new People(); // Create an object called Kevin of People Kevin. aAngryMethod (); // Call the public method after creating this object } } ` const obj3 = ` // Code from filename: People.java // this is an abstract class abstract class People { public String fname = "Kevin"; public int age = 18; public abstract void study(); // abstract method } // Subclass (inherit from People) class Student extends People { public int graduationYear = 2023; public void study() { // the body of the abstract method is provided here System.out.println("He is studying now"); } } // End code from filename: Main.java // Code from filename: Second.java class Second { public static void main(String[] args) { // create an object of the Student class (which inherits attributes and methods from People) Student myObj = new Student(); System.out.println("Name: " + myObj.fname); System.out.println("Age: " + myObj.age); System.out.println("Graduation Year: " + myObj.graduationYear); myObj.study(); // call abstract method } } ` const Code = ({ children }) => ( {children} ); // ---------------- const navigate = useNavigate(); const transfer = (txt) => { if (txt.includes(":)")) { setTimeout(() => navigate('/'), 500); } } const submit = (e) => { e.preventDefault(); const code = document.getElementById("input").value; const data = { code: code }; fetch('/code4', { method: 'POST', headers: { 'Content-Type': 'application/json' }, body: JSON.stringify(data) }) .then(res => res.text()) .then(txt => alert(txt)) // .then(txt => transfer(txt)) } return (

Chapter 7: Java Packages

A Java package is like a file repository that contains all related classes. It is an excellent way to avoid same-name overlaps.

Two categories of packages:
  • Built-in Packages
  • User defined Packages

Built-in Packages

For classes, you can use either public or default:
KeyWord Access Range
 public  The class is accessible by every class.
 default  The class is only accessible by classes which are located in the same package. This happens when you don't specify a modifier. 
For attributes, methods and constructors, you can use the following keyword to control access:
KeyWord Access Range
 public  The code is accessible for all classes in the java file.
 private  The code is just and only accessible within the declared class.  
 default  The class is only accessible by classes which are located in the same package. This happens when you don't specify a modifier.  
 protected  The code is only accessible in the same package and subclasses.  

Non-Access Modifiers

For classes, you can use final / abstract:
KeyWord Access Range
 final  It means this class cannot be inherited by other classes.
 abstract  It means this class cannot be utilized to create objects.  
For attributes and methods, you can use the one of the following:
KeyWord Access Range
 final  Attributes and methods cannot be overridden or changed.
 static  Attributes and methods belong to the class, rather than an object.  
 abstract  Can only be used in an abstract class and can only be used on methods.  
 transient  Attributes and methods are skipped when serializing the object containing them.  
 synchronized  Methods can only be accessed by one thread at a time.  
 volatile  The value of an attribute is not cached thread-locally, and is always read from the "main memory".  

Follow Up

Next three examples will explain more precisely

Final

When you don't want to interrupt the current attribute values, you can declare these attributes using finals:

                        {obj1}

Static

A static method ensures that this method can be accessed without creating an object of the class, which is quite different from public:

An example to show the differences between static and public methods:

                        {obj2}

Abstract

An abstract method belongs to an abstract class, and it does not own a body. Because the body is provided by the subclass:

                        {obj3}
